Description: Fragment of a marble egg-and-dart moulding of an Ionic cyma without Astragal. Fragment shows the remains of two leaves, as well as the lower part of a dart. The light grey marble piece is highly weathered and chipped.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'second temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: Fragment belongs together with B 412 and B 413 to an Ionic cyma with thick, fleshy shaped leaves on a low-lying relief background. Adjoining the fragments B 412 with B 414 the width of the axis as well as the height of the cyma is, though not precisely, reconstructible. The jointed cyma presumably belongs to the corner pieces B 426, B 407, B 409 (reconstruction see Koenigs 2007, 333), however, the profile of the main corner piece differs on its lower ending by proceeding straight. Published (Koenigs 2007, 330f. Cat. 21; Petrie 1886, 14 No. 18, Pl. 14 A; L. Shoe 1936, 17 Pl. 6/14 (reconstructed); Altekamp 137 No. 1, Fig. 123)
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B414)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XIV A, centre)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (no. 21, pp. 330-1, pls 16-17)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.30) (Phase 3)
